chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
If we were worthy to hear the voice of that heavenly trumpet, like the one John heard in the Book of Revelation, which spoke to him, saying: "Come up here and I will show you what must happen after this" (Revelation, chapter four), and if we could join him in spirit, becoming entirely spiritual with nothing earthly or carnal remaining in us, then we would be able to relate the figure of this statue to the text of all divine Scripture in an allegorical sense.

So, since we know the Book of Genesis starts the divine Scriptures, it's reasonable to understand the head of this statue through that book. The Gospel, which the Lord Jesus Christ established, was always hidden in the Old Testament, as the prophet Ezekiel reveals in chapter one, saying he saw a wheel within a wheel, representing the Gospel within the old law.

It's fitting to associate the Gospel with the Book of Genesis as the head, since the law and Gospel sound the same in all respects, containing the same truth, even if expressed in different words. Just as the Book of Genesis and the Gospel represent the head of this statue, it's fitting to take its chest through the books of the prophets. For in the chest, secret plans are hidden, and the holy prophets are known to have foreseen God's secret plans before they happened.

Thus, one of the prophets said: "Your counsel of old is true, O Lord" (Isaiah, chapter twenty-five). As we've mentioned, human labor is often represented in the arms; through the Book of Psalms, the arms of this statue can be rightly prefigured, since these psalms often mention human labor, as in: "See my affliction and my labor" (Psalm twenty-five), and: "They are not in the labor of men" (Psalm seventy-three), along with many similar passages.
chunks.original_latin:
Si essemus digni audire vocem illius tubae coelestis
quam audivit Joannes, sicut ipse dicit in libro Apocalypsis,
quae ad eum locuta est, dicens: Ascende huc
et ostendam tibi quae oportet fieri posthaec (Apoc IV),
et si cum eo ipso possemus esse in spiritu, hoc est, ex
toto effici spirituales, ut nihil carnale, nihil terrenum
 343 in nobis penitus remaneret, tunc possibilitas
nobis subjaceret, quatenus figuram hujus statuae
allegorico sensu referremus ad textum totius divinae
Scripturae. Igitur quoniam Genesis librum principium
divinarum Scripturarum esse non ignoramus,
non immerito per eumdem librum caput hujus statuae
intelligimus. Et quia Evangelium, quod Dominus
Jesus Christus condidit, semper in Veteri
Testamento absconditum fuit, sicut Ezechiel propheta
testatur (cap I), qui rotam in rotam, hoc est Evangelium
in veterem legem se vidisse profitetur. Bene
quidem Evangelium idem eidem libro Genesis in
parte capitis sociamus, quia legem et Evangelium
idem per omnia sonare, itidem prorsus continere,
licet dissimilibus verbis, non dubitamus. Sicut ergo
 per librum Genesis, et per Evangelium, hujus statuae
caput intelligitur, sic justum est ut per libros
prophetarum pectus ejusdem accipiatur. In pectore
enim secreta consilia absconduntur, et sancti prophetae
secreta consilia Dei antequam evenirent,
praescisse dignoscuntur. Unde unus ex eisdem prophetis
dicebat: Consilium tuum, Domine, antiquum
verum fiat (Isa XXV): quia vero, ut supra jam
diximus, in brachiis solet labor humanus designari,
per librum Psalmorum possunt quidem recte brachia
hujus statuae praefigurari, quoniam quidem in
eisdem psalmis persaepe mentio fit humani laboris,
quemadmodum est illud: Vide humilitatem meam
et laborem meum (Psal XXIV), et: In labore hominum
 non sunt (Psal LXXII), et alia multa his
similia.

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
However, as we delve into the books of the Kings, we should take note of the bronze belly of this statue. Just like how many things are hidden within the belly that aren't visible from the outside, the books of the Kings contain many mystical and figurative elements that remain hidden from us.

Since, as we previously mentioned, human offspring come from the thighs, it's fitting that through the letters of Saint Paul and other apostles, the thighs of this statue are understood. Paul, even though he was taken up to the third heaven and heard profound secrets beyond human comprehension, humbly addressed issues of marital relations, saying: "The husband should fulfill his marital duty to his wife, and likewise the wife to her husband, and each one should have their own spouse to avoid sexual immorality." (First Corinthians 7)

Regarding the legs, which seem to support the weight of the whole body, we should consider the writings of modern scholars. These are aptly described as being made of iron because, just as iron overcomes everything, the writings of the saints-namely Ambrose, Jerome, Augustine, and Gregory-destroy and eliminate all heretical teachings.

In the feet made of iron and clay, we interpret the doctrines of Catholics alongside those of heretics, who will be present in the last days. Just as iron cannot solidly combine with clay, the doctrine of the orthodox cannot be reconciled with the corrupt teachings of heretics. As Paul says: "What fellowship can light have with darkness, or what does a believer have in common with an unbeliever?" (Second Corinthians 6)
chunks.original_latin:
Per libros autem Regum debemus intelligere
hujus statuae ventrem aereum, quia sicut in
ventre multa occultantur, quae foris non apparent,
sic in libris Regum multa mystica et figurativa sunt,
quae adhuc nos latent. Et quia, sicut jam praefati
sumus, de femoribus humana propago egreditur,
non inconvenienter per Epistolas beati Pauli et aliorum
apostolorum, femora hujus statuae intelliguntur. Qui Paulus, licet usque ad tertium coelum raptus
sit, et quamvis secreta quaedam, quae ab hominibus
non capiuntur in excessu mentis positus
audierit, tamen ad disponenda carnalium conjugia
humiliter descendit, dicens: Vir debitum reddat
uxori, similiter et uxor viro, et unusquisque suam uxorem
 habeat propter fornicationem (I Cor VIII). Per tibias vero quae totius corporis molem sustinere
videntur, modernorum doctorum Scripturas nos
oportet accipere. Quae quidem bene ferreae fuisse
describuntur, quia sicut ferrum omnia domat, sic
Scripturae sanctorum, videlicet Ambrosii, Hieronymi,
Augustini, Gregorii, omnium haereticorum
dogmata destruunt et eliminant. In pedibus autem ferreis
et fictilibus debemus interpretari doctrinas Catholicorum,
simul et haereticorum, qui erunt in
novissimis diebus, quia sicut ferrum cum luto non
valet solidari, sic doctrina orthodoxorum cum pravis
dogmatibus haereticorum non poterit concordari. Sicut enim dicit Paulus: Quae societas luci ad tenebras,
 aut quae pars fideli cum infideli? (II
Cor. VI.)
